SEARCH
Package co.aikar.taskchain

Class TaskChain<T>

java.lang.Object
co.aikar.taskchain.TaskChain<T>
public class TaskChain<T> extends Object
The Main API class of TaskChain. TaskChain's are created by a TaskChainFactory

    TaskChain<T>
    configure(Consumer<TaskChain<T>> configure)
    Allows you to call a callback to insert tasks into the chain without having to break the fluent interface Example: Plugin.newChain().sync(some::task).configure(chain -> { chain.async(some::foo); chain.sync(other::bar); }).async(other::task).execute();

    <R> TaskChain<R>
    syncFirstFuture(TaskChainTasks.FutureFirstTask<R> task)
    Execute a task on the main thread, with no previous input, that will return a Future to signal completion It's important you don't perform blocking operations in this method.
    <R> TaskChain<List<R>>
    syncFirstFutures(TaskChainTasks.FirstTask<List<CompletableFuture<R>>> task)

    <R> TaskChain<R>
    syncFuture(TaskChainTasks.FutureTask<R,T> task)
    Execute a task on the main thread, with the last output as the input to the future provider, that will return a Future to signal completion.
    <R> TaskChain<List<R>>
    syncFutures(TaskChainTasks.Task<List<CompletableFuture<R>>,T> task)

    TaskChain<?>
    syncLast(TaskChainTasks.LastTask<T> task)
    Execute task on main thread, with the last output, and no furthur output

    Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

    clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

  • Method Details

    • getCurrentActionIndex

      public int getCurrentActionIndex()
      Called in an executing task, get the current action index. For every action that adds a task to the chain, the action index is increased. Useful in error or done handlers to know where you are in the chain when it aborted or threw exception.
      Returns:
      The current index

    • setDoneCallback

      public void setDoneCallback(Consumer<Boolean> doneCallback)
      Changes the done callback handler for this chain
      Parameters:
      doneCallback - The handler

    • getErrorHandler

      public BiConsumer<Exception,TaskChainTasks.Task<?,?>> getErrorHandler()
      Returns:
      The current error handler or null

    • setErrorHandler

      public void setErrorHandler(BiConsumer<Exception,TaskChainTasks.Task<?,?>> errorHandler)
      Changes the error handler for this chain
      Parameters:
      errorHandler - The error handler

    • multi

      public static <D1, D2> TaskChainDataWrappers.Data2<D1,D2> multi(D1 var1, D2 var2)
      Creates a data wrapper to return multiple objects from a task

      Creates a data wrapper to return multiple objects from a task

      public static <D1, D2, D3, D4, D5, D6> TaskChainDataWrappers.Data6<D1,D2,D3,D4,D5,D6> multi(D1 var1, D2 var2, D3 var3, D4 var4, D5 var5, D6 var6)
      Creates a data wrapper to return multiple objects from a task

    • abort

      public static void abort()
      Call to abort execution of the chain. Should be called inside of an executing task.

    • getCurrentChain

      public static TaskChain<?> getCurrentChain()
      Usable only inside of an executing Task or Chain Error/Done handlers Gets the current chain that is executing this Task or Error/Done handler This method should only be called on the same thread that is executing the method. In an AsyncExecutingTask or a FutureTask, You must call this method BEFORE passing control to another thread.

    • configure

      public TaskChain<T> configure(Consumer<TaskChain<T>> configure)
      Allows you to call a callback to insert tasks into the chain without having to break the fluent interface Example: Plugin.newChain().sync(some::task).configure(chain -> { chain.async(some::foo); chain.sync(other::bar); }).async(other::task).execute();
      Parameters:
      configure - Instance of the current chain.
      Returns:
      The same chain

    • hasTaskData

      public boolean hasTaskData(String key)
      Checks if the chain has a value saved for the specified key.
      Parameters:
      key - Key to check if Task Data has a value for

    • getTaskData

      public <R> R getTaskData(String key)
      Retrieves a value relating to a specific key, saved by a previous task.
      Type Parameters:
      R - Type the Task Data value is expected to be
      Parameters:
      key - Key to look up Task Data for

    • setTaskData

      public <R> R setTaskData(String key, Object val)
      Saves a value for this chain so that a task furthur up the chain can access it. Useful for passing multiple values to the next (or furthur) tasks.
      Type Parameters:
      R - Type the Task Data value is expected to be
      Parameters:
      key - Key to store in Task Data
      val - Value to store in Task Data

    • removeTaskData

      public <R> R removeTaskData(String key)
      Removes a saved value on the chain.
      Type Parameters:
      R - Type the Task Data value is expected to be
      Parameters:
      key - Key to remove from Task Data

    • storeAsData

      public TaskChain<T> storeAsData(String key)
      Takes the previous tasks return value, stores it to the specified key as Task Data, and then forwards that value to the next task.
      Parameters:
      key - Key to store the previous return value into Task Data

    • returnData

      public <R> TaskChain<R> returnData(String key)
      Reads the specified key from Task Data, and passes it to the next task. Will need to pass expected type such as chain.<Foo>returnData("key")
      Type Parameters:
      R - Return type that the next parameter can expect as argument type
      Parameters:
      key - Key to retrieve from Task Data and pass to next task

    • returnChain

      public TaskChain<TaskChain<?>> returnChain()
      Returns the chain itself to the next task.

    • delay

      public TaskChain<T> delay(int gameUnits)
      IMPLEMENTATION SPECIFIC!! Consult your application implementation to understand how long 1 unit is. For example, in Minecraft it is a tick, which is roughly 50 milliseconds, but not guaranteed. Adds a delay to the chain execution.
      Parameters:
      gameUnits - # of game units to delay before next task

    • delay

      public TaskChain<T> delay(int duration, TimeUnit unit)
      Adds a real time delay to the chain execution. Chain will abort if the delay is interrupted.
      Parameters:
      duration - duration of the delay before next task

    • abortChain

      public TaskChain<?> abortChain()
      Aborts the chain once this step is reached. This is primarily useful when you are dynamically building the chains steps (such as .configure()) and want to conditionally stop the chain from proceeding.
      Returns:
      Chain

    • abortIfNull

      public TaskChain<T> abortIfNull()
      Checks if the previous task return was null. If not null, the previous task return will forward to the next task.

    • abortIfNull

      public TaskChain<T> abortIfNull(TaskChainAbortAction<?,?,?> action)
      abortIf(Object, TaskChainAbortAction, Object, Object, Object)

    • abortIfNull

      public <A1, A2, A3> TaskChain<T> abortIfNull(TaskChainAbortAction<A1,A2,A3> action, A1 arg1, A2 arg2, A3 arg3)
      Checks if the previous task return was null, and aborts if it was Then executes supplied action handler If not null, the previous task return will forward to the next task.

    • abortIf

      public TaskChain<T> abortIf(T ifObj)
      Checks if the previous task return is the supplied value. If not, the previous task return will forward to the next task.

      abortIf(Predicate, TaskChainAbortAction, Object, Object, Object)

    • abortIf

      public TaskChain<T> abortIf(Predicate<T> predicate)
      Checks if the previous task return matches the supplied predicate, and aborts if it was. If predicate does not match, the previous task return will forward to the next task.

    • abortIf

      abortIf(Object, TaskChainAbortAction, Object, Object, Object)

    • abortIf

      public <A1, A2, A3> TaskChain<T> abortIf(Predicate<T> predicate, TaskChainAbortAction<A1,A2,A3> action, A1 arg1, A2 arg2, A3 arg3)
      Checks if the previous task return matches the supplied predicate, and aborts if it was. Then executes supplied action handler If predicate does not match, the previous task return will forward to the next task.

    • syncFirstCallback

      public <R> TaskChain<R> syncFirstCallback(TaskChainTasks.AsyncExecutingFirstTask<R> task)
      Execute a task on the main thread, with no previous input, and a callback to return the response to. It's important you don't perform blocking operations in this method. Only use this if the task will be scheduling a different sync operation outside of the TaskChains scope. Usually you could achieve the same design with a blocking API by switching to an async task for the next task and running it there. This method would primarily be for cases where you need to use an API that ONLY provides a callback style API.
      Type Parameters:
      R - Return type that the next parameter can expect as argument type
      Parameters:
      task - The task to execute

    • asyncFirstCallback

      syncFirstCallback(AsyncExecutingFirstTask) but ran off main thread
      Type Parameters:

      Parameters:

    • syncCallback

      public <R> TaskChain<R> syncCallback(TaskChainTasks.AsyncExecutingTask<R,T> task)
      Execute a task on the main thread, with the last output, and a callback to return the response to. It's important you don't perform blocking operations in this method. Only use this if the task will be scheduling a different sync operation outside of the TaskChains scope. Usually you could achieve the same design with a blocking API by switching to an async task for the next task and running it there. This method would primarily be for cases where you need to use an API that ONLY provides a callback style API.
      Type Parameters:
      R - Return type that the next parameter can expect as argument type
      Parameters:
      task - The task to execute

    • future

      public <R> TaskChain<R> future(CompletableFuture<R> future)
      Takes a supplied Future, and holds processing of the chain until the future completes. The value of the Future will be passed until the next task.
      Type Parameters:
      R - Return type that the next parameter can expect as argument type
      Parameters:
      future - The Future to wait until it is complete on

    • futures

      @SafeVarargs public final <R> TaskChain<List<R>> futures(CompletableFuture<R>... futures)
      Takes multiple supplied Futures, and holds processing of the chain until the futures completes. The results of the Futures will be passed until the next task.
      Type Parameters:
      R - Return type that the next parameter can expect as argument type
      Parameters:
      futures - The Futures to wait until it is complete on

    • futures

      public <R> TaskChain<List<R>> futures(List<CompletableFuture<R>> futures)

      Type Parameters:
      R - Return type that the next parameter can expect as argument type
      Parameters:
      futures - The Futures to wait until it is complete on

    • syncFutures

      public <R> TaskChain<List<R>> syncFutures(TaskChainTasks.Task<List<CompletableFuture<R>>,T> task)
      Executes a Task on the Main thread that provides a list of Futures, and holds processing of the chain until all of the futures completes. The response of every future will be passed to the next task as a List, in the order the futures were supplied.
      Type Parameters:
      R - Return type that the next parameter can expect as argument type
      Parameters:
      task - The Futures Provider Task

    • asyncFutures

      public <R> TaskChain<List<R>> asyncFutures(TaskChainTasks.Task<List<CompletableFuture<R>>,T> task)
      Executes a Task off the Main thread that provides a list of Futures, and holds processing of the chain until all of the futures completes. The response of every future will be passed to the next task as a List, in the order the futures were supplied.

      R - Return type that the next parameter can expect as argument type
      Parameters:
      task - The Futures Provider Task

      public void execute()
      Finished adding tasks, begins executing them.

    • execute

      public void execute(Runnable done)
      Finished adding tasks, begins executing them with a done notifier
      Parameters:
      done - The Callback to handle when the chain has finished completion. Argument to consumer contains finish state
